I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During stakeholder consultations and programming discussions with the Government of 
India (GOI) in January 2009, it became clear that ADB should strengthen the environmental 
focus of its India assistance program. Accordingly, the loan and technical assistance (TA) 
program was designed to support GOI's efforts in the areas of adaptation and mitigation. 
Support for the National Action Plan on Climate Change (SNAPCC) is one such TA Project 
included at the request of the Government  
 
2.  Since March 2009, ADB consultations in India on developing the South Asia Regional 
Department  climate  change  implementation  plan  were  held  with  the  Ministry  of  Water 
Resources (MOWR), reputed climate change experts, and development partners. Consultation 
has continued with the government. This TA has been developed following a request from the 
Department of Economic Affairs on behalf of MOWR for ADB to assist the preparation of 
specific  studies  that  would  help  operationalize  the  National  Water  Mission  (NWM)  of  the 
National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC).1 Several meetings have been held with the 
government,  during  which  possible  approaches  to  support  the  NWM  were  discussed  and 
refined. A meeting was held with the MOWR and representatives from a number of water 
agencies from the central and state governments on 28 October 2009. At the meeting, a 
suggested approach to the support program was presented and discussed, useful comments 
and suggestions were made, and these have been incorporated into the TA report. Preliminary 
understandings and agreements have been reached on TA impact, outcome, implementation 
arrangements,  cost  estimates,  and  consultants’  terms  of  reference.2  The  TA  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Adapting to climate variability and change has long been part of water planning and 
management, but the current pace of climate change is unprecedented, so experience to date is 
unlikely to be sufficient to guide an acceptable way forward. While climate change predictions 
on a global or regional scale are quite robust, large uncertainties remain in projections of climate 
change  impacts  on  hydrology  at  the  basin  level.  Water  resource  managers  and  planners 
urgently need information and direction to plan the way forward.  
 
4.  India's position on climate change issues and government response.3 India is and 
will  continue  to  be  severely  affected  by  climate  variability  while  confronted  with  huge 
development imperatives. For India, the focus of climate change action cannot just be emissions 
but must equally address adaptation. India is already subject to high climate variability, resulting 
in droughts, floods, and other extreme weather. In an address to the National Conference of 
Ministers  of  Environment  and  Forests  on  August  2009,  Prime  Minister  Manmohan  Singh 
encouraged state governments to create action plans on climate change consistent with the 
strategies  of  the  NAPCC.  The  government's  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan,  2007–2012  clearly 
articulates the impacts and implications of climate change noted in Intergovernmental Panel on 
Climate Change assessment reports. To meaningfully address some of the threats of climate 
change,  the  government  unveiled  on  30  June  2008  its  NAPCC.  The  NAPCC  proposes

establishing eight national missions,4 each to be managed by ministries and line agencies 
through inter-sectoral groups including related ministries; the Ministry of Finance; the Planning 
Commission, and experts from industry, academia, and civil society. Each mission is preparing 
detailed implementation plans under the 11th and 12th (2010-2017) plans. 
 
5.  India's  hydro-climatic  future. India is highly vulnerable to climate change. Current 
pressures  on  water  resources  are  extremely  challenging,  as  variations  and  extremes  of 
hydrology combine with population growth and poverty. To adapt to anticipated climate change, 
it is essential to coordinate water management practices and optimize the operation of water 
infrastructure consistent with sustainable development and the availability of water. The NWM 
has identified a wide range of issues and possible responses, from which three major areas of 
concern stand out: (i) alterations of winter snow pack dynamics on snow-fed river systems, (ii) 
basins where groundwater is major water source, and (iii) coastal areas where sea level rise will 
affect surface water and groundwater.  
 
6.  Opportunities for Asian Development Bank support. In its request for assistance, the 
MOWR identified three areas of possible support: (i) integrated water resources management 
(IWRM)  studies  on  selected  river  basins  or  sub-basins;  (ii)  strategic  programs  for  pilot 
demonstration of improved water-use efficiency, and (iii) strengthening institutional strategies 
and capacity, including support from international experts for identified areas of climate change 
research and support for community mobilization and awareness. Supplementary Appendix 2 
presents an analysis of the linkages between the NWM and SNAPCC activities and output.  
 
7.  Linkages with development planning. The 11th Plan recognizes the urgent need to 
balance the trade off  between economic growth and environmental protection, considering 
pressures posed by India's large population, economic growth, and ever-increasing demand on 
natural resources including water. The environmental orientation of ADB’s assistance for both 
adaptation and mitigation has therefore been strengthened to support 11th plan priorities. The 
TA is therefore particularly significant, as it will support operationalizing the NWM established 
under NAPCC. The NWM is a critical requirement for adaptation and will enable the MOWR to 
play a strategic role over the longer term in building capacity in other ministries and state line 
agencies to manage planning for climate change adaptation effectively in their sectors.5 This TA 
complements other TA and loan projects being processed by ADB and will place ADB in a 
unique position among development partners in terms of assisting India's efforts in climate 
change adaptation. The TA outputs will contribute directly to states’ development of climate 
change action plans, which is a high priority for the government. 
 
8.  Integrated water resource management. IWRM is an effective tool for delivering water 
services better by coordinating and balancing various water users. When applied strategically, 
the approach can enhance water security and adaptation to water-related risks. Successful 
IWRM under climate change requires integrating the management of supply and demand and 
developing strong links among research, monitoring, and management. National and state 
governments will require considerable support to meet these challenges. The NWM clearly 
identifies IWRM at the basin level as the foundation upon which the implementation of climate 
change adaptation and impact assessments can be realized. In parallel with IWRM, individual

water sectors must independently move forward to achieve significantly more effective and 
sustainable management. Each sector should develop targets through the IWRM program, as 
improving  efficiency  in  water  sectors  is  fundamental  to  climate  change  adaptation.  The 
application of river basin organizations may be considered if deemed appropriate. 
 
9.  Guidance  in  decision  making  under  uncertainty.  Uncertainty  in  climate  change 
scenarios and the limitations of simulations degrade the value of historical data in guiding water 
resource decisions. Although understanding of the impacts of climate change continues to 
improve, it is still difficult to predict regional impacts with precision. This uncertainty is a major 
constraint on formulating and implementing adaptation policies. Simulating projected climate 
change scenarios and assessing the sensitivity of basin water resources to these changes may 
form  the  basis  of  a  step-by-step  progression  from  general  to  more  specific  and  accurate 
assessments to support the design of cost-effective adaptation.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be enhanced resilience to climate change affecting vulnerable 
sectors and populations though strategic support to India’s NAPCC. The outcome of the TA will 
be a preliminary IWRM approach to climate adaptation supported by government. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The main outputs of the TA are described below6.  
 
12.   Preparing strategic frameworks for IWRM to address climate uncertainty. The TA 
will undertake studies in up to three pilot basins or sub-basins to develop strategy frameworks 
for addressing current and likely future scenarios of climate change. Framework planning will 
build on the proposals of the NWM and international best practices and address how climate 
uncertainties can be incorporated into mainstream planning. The studies will review national and 
international projections of climate parameters, identify data gaps, and assess the viability of 
applying them to support decision making. Framework planning will be applied to identify key 
issues affecting surface water, groundwater, related water sectors, and the environment. The 
plans will set out broad strategies and programs to make water systems more robust and 
resilient  against  climate  change  uncertainty,  while  meeting  rising  water  demand  and 
environmental requirements. Pilot basins will be selected by type and likely degree of sensitivity 
to  climate  change.  Basin  selection  should  incorporate  three  major  areas  of  concern:  (i) 
alterations of winter snow pack dynamics from climate change, (ii) basins or sub-basins where 
groundwater is major water source, and (iii) coastal areas where sea level rise will have impacts 
on surface water and groundwater.  
 
13.   Assessing the potential for improving water-use efficiency. Through the work in the 
pilot  sub-basins,  the  TA  will  examine  intervention  requirements,  scope,  and  strategies  to 
improve the efficiency of water systems and study how improved efficiency may be applied to 
climate  change  adaptation.  Studies  may  include  (i)  options  for  improving  management 
organizations to address poor service delivery and cost recovery; (ii) the conjunctive use of 
surface water and groundwater; (iii) the potential for structural improvements including water

reuse and improved distribution systems; (iv) a review of water-allocation systems and the 
potential for volumetric water allocation and establishing effective regulation and control; (v) 
alternative  and  appropriate  arrangements  to  initiate  and  develop  sustainable  change  and 
strategies for scaling up, including private sector participation or other management initiatives; 
(vi) assessing legal frameworks and mandates; and (vii) identifying appropriate indicators and 
monitoring.  
 
14.   Road map for effective institutions, specialist training, and awareness. The TA will 
provide technical, institutional, and other expertise to identify requirements for establishing 
effective IWRM systems under likely climate change scenarios. This will include preparing 
preliminary IWRM climate change adaptation road maps for states based on consultations with 
state governments and supported by outputs of investigations in the selected pilot sub-basins. A 
preliminary climate change adaptation roadmap will be prepared for the MOWR incorporating 
the broad proposals for effective and integrated management, addressing national and state 
needs. Information in the road maps will include (i) issues derived from state information and 
consultation  and  from  the  outputs  of  strategic  framework  planning  for  the  sub-basins;  (ii) 
assessment  of  sector  responsibilities  and  effective  institutional  arrangements  for  managing 
water resources and sectoral coordination; (iii) outline proposals for appropriate institutions to 
address issues such as water control, regulation, tariffs, and allocations; (iv) institutional and 
control strategies to manage and control groundwater and surface water usage for ensuring 
compliance  with  environmental  regulations;  (iv)  identifying  new  management  initiatives  to 
address likely climate change effects, including the potential involvement of the private sector in 
research, planning design, management, and investment; and (v) assessing current and future 
requirements for research related to climate change and the links to planning and managing 
water resources. The TA will prepare specialist training modules, with training materials for 
information,  education,  and  communications  modified  for  the  Indian  context.  International 
climate experts will give presentations on climate and hydrological topics. Workshops will be 
held on key issues and include invitations to international and national speakers to create better 
understanding of climate change and promote links. 
 
15.  To supplement the preliminary findings of the TA, it is proposed that selected national 
institutes undertake various parallel studies.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA (Appendix 2) is estimated to cost $925,000 equivalent, of which $750,000  will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund 7.  The Government, through MOWR, 
will finance the remaining $175,000 equivalent by providing office space, transport, counterpart 
staff, data analysis and other administrative costs. The Government would also provide funds 
for parallel studies by National Institutes and the costs of dissemination and broadcasting of 
awareness materials.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The MOWR will be the executing agency and appoint a senior technical director and/or 
national coordinator. An interdepartmental project working group will be established to help 
direct and support the programming of activities. It will be chaired by the project technical 
director and include representatives from the MOWR, Central Water Commission, Planning 
Commission, related ministries, representatives of the pilot basin states, and selected sector 
                                                 
7 ADB-(2008). Doc. R59-08, Climate Change Fund, 18 March, Manila.

5
 
specialists. In parallel, a senior steering committee will be established to provide guidance, 
direction on policy, and support for endorsing the study findings. It will be chaired by the 
secretary of the MOWR and include senior representatives from other ministries including the 
Ministry of Finance and specialists in related areas. Studies in the pilot basins will be supported 
through state project directors and working groups.  
 
18.  The TA will be implemented in three phases over 12 months tentatively planned from 
April 2010 to March 2011. Phases 1 and 2 to be completed over the first 7 months and develop 
the IWRM basin framework studies, state road maps, and other studies. Over the subsequent 5 
months, phase 3 of the TA will support applying the outputs from the pilot basin studies to 
develop  a  national  IWRM  road  map,  training,  workshops,  consultations,  and  information 
dissemination on related activities. All equipment for the TA will be procured according to ADB 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  A  team  of  international 
consultants will be engaged for 13 person-months, and national consultants for 25 person-
months, to implement the TA. A total of 13 experts will be engaged in accordance with ADB 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Given  the 
specialized nature of the work and ADB’s recent entry into the climate change arena in India, 
this  TA  will  require  more  specialized  management.  It  is  proposed  that  ADB  recruit  all 
consultants individually in consultation with the government. This will provide the best mix of 
consultants with the most appropriate qualifications and experience. Outline terms of reference 
for the consultants are in Appendix 3. TA progress will be measured as stipulated in the design 
and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). The TA outputs will be disseminated in state and 
national workshops and through local capacity-building and training workshops. Disbursements 
under the TA will be made in accordance with the ADB Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook8.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of India for Support for the National Action Plan on Climate Change, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

A.  Scope of Services 
 
2.  Part  A:  preliminary  sub-basin  strategic  framework  plans  for  three  sub-basins. 
Strategic framework planning studies will be implemented in up to three pilot basins or sub-basins. 
These will be IWRM studies with a focus on developing preliminary strategies for addressing 
present uncertainty regarding climate change and likely greater future uncertainty. Framework 
planning will build on the proposals by National Water Mission (NWM) and international best 
practices and address IWRM issues and how climate change uncertainty can be incorporated into 
planning. The studies will review national and international projections of climate parameters, 
identify  data  gaps,  and  assess  the  viability  of  applying  them  to  support  decision  making. 
Framework planning will be applied to identify key issues regarding surface water, groundwater, 
related water sectors, and the environment. The plans will set out broad strategies and programs 
to make water systems more robust against climate change uncertainty and meet rising water 
demand and environmental requirements. Up to three pilot basins will be selected by type and 
likely degree of sensitivity to climate change, and they should be at a workable scale. Basin 
selection should incorporate three major areas of concern: (i) alterations of winter snow pack 
dynamics from climate change; (ii) basins or sub-basins where groundwater is major water source, 
and (iii) coastal areas where sea level rise will affect surface water and groundwater. The outputs 
will be a strategic plan for each of the three sub-basins with common annexes where appropriate.  
3.  The main activities will be to (i) prepare broad technical assessments of key water issues in 
the sub-basins; (ii) assess data management systems and river basin models where they exist; (iii) 
develop a basic geographic information system (GIS) to assemble spatial data for preliminary

Appendix 3  11 
planning; (iv) work with stakeholders at the state and sub-basin level to identify a strategic vision 
and objectives for IWRM and possible adaptation measures to meet climate change uncertainties; 
(v) identify institutional enhancements and possible investment projects to achieve the vision and 
objectives; and (vi) identify possible management and investment scenarios to meet the long-term 
need for efficiency, improved service delivery, and cost recovery, including the potential roles of 
government, stakeholders, and the private sector.  
 
4.  Part B: water efficiency improvement assessment. Through the work in the pilot sub-
basins,  the  TA  will  examine  intervention  requirements,  scope,  and  strategies  to  improve  the 
efficiency  of  water  systems  and  study  how  climate  change  dimensions  may  effectively  be 
incorporated. Studies will include (i) options for improving management organizations, building on 
existing  structures  but  addressing  urgent  needs  to  address  poor  service  delivery  and  cost 
recovery; (ii) the conjunctive use of surface water and groundwater; (iii) the potential for structural 
improvements including water reuse and improved distribution systems; (iv) a review of water-
allocation systems and the potential for volumetric water allocation supported by establishing 
effective  regulation  and  controls;  (v)  alternative  and  appropriate  arrangements  to  initiate  and 
develop sustainable change and strategies for scaling up, including the provision of private sector 
or other appropriate management support initiatives; (vi) assessing legal frameworks or mandates; 
and (vii) identifying appropriate indicators and monitoring frameworks.  
5.  Part C:  preliminary state IWRM climate change adaptation road map. Preliminary and 
outline IWRM climate change adaptation roadmaps will be prepared for the states where the pilot 
sub-basins  are  located.  The  state  IWRM  roadmaps  will  identify  the  broad  requirements  for 
establishing  effective  IWRM  systems  under  climate  change.  Information  in  the  roadmaps  will 
include (i) broad water issues in the state, incorporating the experiences from pilot sub-basins; (ii) 
assessment of requisite functions and sector responsibilities at different levels and broad proposals 
for effective institutional arrangements for water resources management and sectoral coordination; 
(iii)  outline  proposals  for  appropriate  institutions  to  address  such  issues  as  water  control, 
regulation, tariffs, and allocations; (iv) identifying institutional and control strategies to manage and 
control groundwater and surface water use, ensuring requirements for a healthy environment; (v) 
identifying new management initiatives to meet the scale and necessary speed of change required 
to adapt to likely climate effects, including the application of private sector support for research, 
planning design, management, and investment; (vi) assessing ongoing research and broad future 
requirements for research related to climate change and the links to water resources planning and 
management.  State  working  groups  will  be  key  forums  for  interaction  and  preparing  state 
roadmaps. 
6.  Part D: preliminary IWRM climate change adaptation roadmap for MOWR addressing 
national and state needs. By applying the outputs from the three state road maps, together with 
parallel ADB-supported programs and other state and national experiences,1  a preliminary IWRM 
climate change adaptation road map will be prepared for the MOWR for effective and integrated 
management by states and the center. The road map will identify the broad national and state 
needs to implement IWRM and delineate responsibilities for data management, including proposals 
for  integrated  data  management;  data  sharing  initiatives;  and  possibly  setting  up  river  basin 
organizations. Scale, scope, resources, and time frames will be defined to effectively meet the 
challenges of IWRM and climate change adaptation.  
7.  Part E:  IWRM training modules, awareness kits, and specialist training. The TA will 
prepare specialist training modules in key areas. Training material will draw on parallel ADB 
programs for information, education, and communications and other climate and IWRM information 
                                                 
1 The ADB-supported IWRM and service delivery TA in Karnataka will be of special relevance.

12       Appendix 3 
sources, with material modified for the Indian situation. International climate experts will give 
presentations on climate and hydrological topics. A series of workshops will be held to address key 
issues and include invitations to key international speakers to create understanding of climate 
change and promote links. 
B.  Reporting and Workshops 
8.  The consultants will produce the following reports.2 
(i)  The inception report at the end of the first month of TA implementation will present 
initial  TA  findings  and  assessments  and  methods  for  preparing  pilot  basin 
framework  plans  and  road  maps.  The  inception  report  will  be  discussed  with 
stakeholders at an inception workshop held 2 weeks after its submission. 
(ii)  The midterm report at the end of month 7 will present the draft strategic framework 
plans  and  preliminary  road  maps  for  the  sub-basins.  The  plans  will  present 
diagnoses  and  analyses  of  the  pilot  sub-basins  and  system  performance, 
management,  operations  and  maintenance,  funding,  and  outline  scenarios  for 
improving practices and management arrangements. The midterm report and its 
preliminary  recommendations  will  be  discussed  with  stakeholders  at  a  midterm 
workshop held 4 weeks after its submission.  
(iii)  Workshops will be held in each of the three states in month 8 to support the 
preparation of the state road maps. 
(iv)  The draft final report at the end of month 10 will present all the main outputs of the 
study in draft form. 
(v)  The final report, to be submitted 8 weeks after the final workshop, will allow good 
time to take into account the comments and views expressed at the workshop and 
all other official comments. 
(vi)  The  final  workshop  will  incorporate,  over  and  above  project  activities,  a  wider 
strategic  conference  on  IWRM  climate  change  adaptation  strategies.  The 
conference  will  combine  experiences  from  the  studies  with  other  research  and 
studies  in  India  and  internationally.  National  and  international  speakers  will  be 
invited to participate in this conference. 
 
C.  Facilities to be Provided by the Ministry of Water Resources 
9.  The MOWR will provide, in coordination with pilot sub-basin state agencies, the following 
facilities to the TA team: (i) access to subproject sites, survey and design data, project reports, 
records, and other information required for the TA studies; (ii) office space in Delhi and occasional 
office space in the states; (iii) drivers and guides for field surveys; (iv) four counterpart technical 
staff who will work with the consultants throughout TA implementation;3 (v) parallel support from 
selected national institutes to support the studies and provide information to the study at the 
inception stage; (vi) support for a specialist climate review panel to review and assess climate 
research needs; and (vii) support for the dissemination of training and public awareness materials 
prepared by the TA.
